content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are highly cautious and generally avoid taking risks. You need substantial reassurance and certainty before making decisions. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a cautious and risk-averse person, I would choose a strategy that minimizes losses and maximizes potential gains while maintaining a balance between consistency and flexibility. In this game, both choices (R and B) have advantages and disadvantages.

If I pick R consistently and my anonymous partner picks B in some rounds, I will end up with 0$ in those rounds but still earn 12$ in the other 64 rounds (since we both pick B). This means that even with a few losses, I can still secure a decent payoff.

On the other hand, if my anonymous partner picks R consistently and I choose B, they will earn more than me. However, since I am risk-averse, I prioritize minimizing losses over maximizing potential gains in this scenario.

To minimize losses, it would be wise to play a mixed strategy that does not always pick the same choice. A simple approach could be alternating between R and B in each round (RRBRRB...), as this way, I would have a 50% chance of losing money in any given round compared to having a 100% chance if I were to always pick the same letter.

In conclusion, my choice is to play a mixed strategy that alternates between R and B (R-B-R-B...). {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

Given that I am playing a mixed strategy to minimize losses, my strategy involves alternating between R and B in each round. As I just played R and lost, it would be logical for me to switch to B in the next round since I already played R.

Therefore, my choice for the next round is {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this case, I picked B, my opponent picked R, and I received a higher payoff of 42$ while my opponent earned nothing. If we continue with the mixed strategy of alternating between R and B in each round, it would be reasonable to stick with the same choice (B) since it led to a positive outcome this time.

Therefore, my choice for the next round is {B}.
